questions.question: Which of the following are valid Python variable names? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Valid names start with a letter or underscore, can contain letters/numbers/underscores, and can't be Python keywords. '2nd_place' starts with a number, 'class' is a keyword, and 'my-variable' contains a hyphen.

questions.question: What is the data type of the value 3.14?
questions.explanation: Numbers with decimal points are floats in Python. Integers (int) are whole numbers without decimals.

questions.question: Arrange these type conversions in the order they would be needed to: take user input '25', add 5 to it, then display 'Age: 30'

items.text: Convert to string or use f-string for output

questions.explanation: User input is always a string. To do math, convert to int. For output with text, convert back to string or use f-strings.

questions.question: What will be the output of: print(type(True))?
questions.explanation: True and False are boolean values, so type(True) returns <class 'bool'>.

questions.question: Which of these correctly creates a formatted string showing 'Hello, Alice!'? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: F-strings use curly braces {name} to insert variables. 'Hello, name!' just prints the literal word 'name'. String concatenation with + also works.
